headline: President Trump downplays tit-for-tat tariff hikes with China
subHeadline: Trump says he can still get a new trade deal with Beijing across the goal line; chief White House correspondent John Roberts reports.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. Hey, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Katie Pavlich, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters. That she logged rolls on a pencil. Dana Perino. “The Five.” We are 18 months away and the Republicans already have their guy. The Dems they're narrowing their choices down from what a Republican operative called one big socialist organism with 22 heads. Which you assume some of these people actually have heads.  The Democratic Party responds, every time we try to help the underdog, you call it socialism when actually socialism is all about creating underdogs. The Dems have the ends and none of the means promising lots of toys from Santa with they're trying to build a workshop. Which is why at the end of every false promise it's always soaks the rich until there are no rich people left except their rich friends of course.  And it never works because even in a free market you can't bankroll a left- wing money pit. Venezuela was rich once upon a time. But will this next election be another clash between the R's and the D's or not.  Panic hasn't hit the Dems yet because they haven't learned a damn thing from 2016. The lessons are clear. The healthiest whitest swath of America hates politicians and the media who selects them. It's healthy perspective for it opens the door to candidates who don't fit into boxes or change their accent or fake, phony cadences. The Dems when you think about it could use one of these.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I have to tell you that runway is like an ice-skating rink and the first step I said you know this sucker is slippery. I think it was put in by the Democrats. That's a trap. I'm telling you. It's like - it's like ridiculous. Can you imagine if I went down, the press would have a field day for weeks and weeks? As I stand here floating around on a piece of ice. This is great. This is our worse day on stage I've ever seen. Stupid people did this one. No, no. Or brilliant.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. You can laugh all you want but that's a political phenomenon born from exhaustion. People got sick of the game. So, if the old politician was the bubblegum rock of the 1970s, Trump was the punk rocker who cleared the field. Will the Dems find their own Ramon, their own Johnny Rotten? Don't ask the Dems. They haven't had the slightest clue. We have lots of fun stuff, lot of tape today. And the best probably is Beto on The View. We have to talk about that.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.sentences: We have to talk.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Let's go to that thing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: -- with more because you're a man.

utterances.speaker: FMR. REP. BETO O'ROURKE, D-TX, PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: You're right, there are things that I have been privileged to do in my life that others cannot.

utterances.speaker: JOY BEHAR, HOST, ABC
utterances.sentences: Would you say those are mistakes, being on the cover of Vanity Fair?

utterances.speaker: O'ROURKE
utterances.sentences: Yes. So, it makes --

utterances.speaker: BEHAR
utterances.sentences: It looks elitist?

utterances.speaker: O'ROURKE
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. I think it reinforces that perception of privilege.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, there's probably nothing less attractive than that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, here's -- I think Biden's entry into the race that's really scrambled the whole thing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But now you have all of these superstars or like superstars for a couple weeks at least saying OK, wait, now I'm way down in the polls. They're not getting any traction. Lost some staffers, reconvened, reboot, revamp. And he goes on there and I kind of liked it when he was arrogant guy on the thing waving his arms around.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Like standing on tables. That was a lot more appealing than agreeing that he is nothing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He looks small. He looks small.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It has taken something away from him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Like they have removed something.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. My puppy just had that procedure and he wears the cone of shame. Maybe Beto needs to prop that around his neck.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't understand know who is trying to appeal to with that answer because, well, maybe it's The View audience. I don't know. I kind of liked it when he was being himself and now, he feels overmanaged.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: KATIE PAVLICH, CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: It reinforces this idea that politicians will say whatever they have to depending on the audience.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: So, if it was for The View audience, that's not the audience that's going to get you the votes in the early stage that you need to get up in the polls.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That is true.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It's so inauthentic. And he was supposed to be authentic cool guy --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- with a skateboard and everything he's done so far is completely phony.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's the -- it's that -- you know, OK, the experiment where they put Trump in that seat.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: If they asked him that question.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Like, well, no, I'm not going to apologize for that. What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And if Joy Behar can get him to change his position, what do you think China is going to do?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right. Exactly.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.sentences: Come on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: China is going to say take that back, Beto. And he'll say OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You mean Blac Chyna? Or Chynna Phillips?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: China the country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK. I just want to make sure because we're talking about The View.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm glad you hear --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He what?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But you know what, hang on. You know, I think, in fact, when he said that, he is speaking to The View audience. And he was speaking about there was criticism as I recall from Kamala Harris and others that said look, this guy shows up and he gets on the cover of --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Was it Vanity Fair?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: With his four dogs.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And he gets on the cover because all of a sudden he's the flavor of the day, he looks -- he's so handsome he looks like Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Kennedy. (Inaudible) Kennedy?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. But you know, but then what's really held him down, you notice his numbers have not gone up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Nope.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And I think part of it is people started to see him as the rich kid.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The kid who had a car accident left the scene and all the rest.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Like a Kennedy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And the kid who has not only lots of money but his wife is a zillionaire apparently.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And so, I think this has change the perception. So, I think he is speaking to American women when he says yes, I understand that being a man comes with certain benefits, especially in the world of politics. You don't hear people complaining about his voice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But he had also -- he has also recently done something pretty incredible. Right? He had raised tens of millions of dollars not necessarily all from Texas. Gave Ted Cruz a run for his money. I mean, obviously, Ted Cruz beat him handily but he actually had done something. So, one of the reasons he gets on Vanity Fair cover is because he is willing to do it. And if you want to have a good press like that, you want to be on the cover of Vanity Fair. Well, let Vanity Fair ride around with you like he did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That was -- it wasn't all glowing that piece.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But Vanity Fair, it would embrace him. They -- I don't think Vanity Fair would do that kind of thing with the conservative upstart.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No. But they have done it with Kamala Harris?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think Beto can sell more magazines than Kamala Harris.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Maybe.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This guy is dreamy. He's got the shirt.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dreamy?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He wears the same shirt every single shot. And this was supposed to be the new Kennedy and that's what they were trying to propel him into, and obviously it fizzled out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, what about, OK, what about Kirsten Gillibrand. OK. She is blaming her low poll numbers her failing campaign on gender bias. But she is calling the Democratic voters sexist because not that Republicans --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- that are paying attention to, she is around below 3 percent. So, she is just calling the Dems a bunch of sexists.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, that's why the Trump campaign has much leverage when it comes to the primary with all of these candidates eating each other alive because they don't have to do any of this work in terms of what they're saying and making nonarguments. The reason why Kirsten Gillibrand is at the bottom goes back to the inauthentic thing. Again, if you look at the policy positions she's put forward, in terms of the questions she's been asked at town halls or in her videos or she's lifting weights and doing all these things, that are trying so hard, playing beer pong. Instead of just being inauthentic and not changing her position. She used to be for ICE, she's now against ICE. She is to be pro-NRA, she's now anti- NRA. And she hasn't been able to explain why in a coherent way that doesn't look like pandering. She has changed her policy positions in such an extreme fashion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't think she hasn't developed a clear message. I don't know what the messages from her campaign. I can pick the others but I can't pick her. I will say that to get back to the top of the segment when we're talking about socialism, I just find it so striking that they say yes, the Democrats are all socialists. I'm thinking really, who? Are you saying Kamala Harris is a socialist?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, she did say she wanted to destroy private health insurance.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no. hang no. That's not a socialist to say we need to talk about how to deliver quality health care to more Americans.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: To illegal immigrants.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Pete Buttigieg is not a socialist. Joe Biden is not a socialist.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Some of their positions are socialistic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It seems to me this is an --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Like the Green New Deal.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- opportunity, it's an effort by people in the Trump campaign to get away from talking about real ideas for real solutions and it's a get away from Trump's failed promises on the wall, on healthcare, on infrastructure. No --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana is rolling her eyes. Go for it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They have -- I was breathing deeply. They -- what is the deal in politics? You try to define your opponent early.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The Democrats have tried to define President Trump from the very beginning, for all the things. Like you could list them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Insane, unstable.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The Trump campaign just happens to be doing that now to the Democrats and they left themselves open for this criticism.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But it's not true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, Juan --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The socialist --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: When did that matter? When did that matter?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I agree. You know what, I take your point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If you support the Green New Deal and confiscating people's private health insurance and giving it to the government --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Get out of here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- gun confiscation, raising taxes, (Inaudible) spending. Those types of things are socialist policies.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait a second.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You might not agree about how they're selling it but the policies --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Here --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: One last point. Here is like, we are on a day when Trump has said yes, I was going to get you a deal with China. Do we have a deal? No, no.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I'm just wondering --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Tariffs. We have a lot of those.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Can you define the difference between a Democratic socialist and a socialist.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A socialist, a socialist estate owned means a production, my friend. we don't have any --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That would be the health care plan?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Just like the Democrats. All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That would be the healthcare plan that you --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Get out of here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. I'm putting on my important tease glasses. This is when we are teasing. All right. Attorney General Barr appointing a top prosecutor to find out how the Russian probe started. The latest, next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Attorney General Bill Barr is making good on this promise to investigate the investigators. He's appointed top federal prosecutor John Durham to dig into the origins of the FBI Russia probe and to also determine if the surveillance of the Trump 2016 campaign was warranted. A source says Durham has already been working on this review for several weeks. This comes after Barr told lawmakers last month, he believes Trump campaign spying did occur.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM BARR, ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: I think spying on a political campaign is a big deal. I think spying did occur.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.sentences: But the question was whether it was predicated. Adequately predicated. And I'm not suggesting it wasn't adequately predicated but I need to explore that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And just days after stepping down at the Justice Department, Rod Rosenstein is unloading on James Coney for questioning his character.

utterances.speaker: ROD ROSENSTEIN, FORMER DEPUTY ATTORNEY GENERAL
utterances.sentences: So, I do not blame the former director for being angry. I would be too if I were in his shoes. But now the former director seems to be acting as a partisan pundit, selling books and earning speaking fees while speculating about the strength of my character and the fate of my immortal soul. That is disappointing. Speculating about souls is not a job for police and prosecutors. Generally, we base our opinions on eyewitness testimony.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Greg, Rosenstein is mad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He certainly was. And he's right because we talked about this before that talking about your soul. That's not a fact. It's just some kind of -- he is assessing the psychological disorder. He's reading minds. But he was right when he called Comey a pundit because Comey is a victim of the seductive media spotlight and the strange new respect that you get. We've seen it with Mitt Romney, we've seen with Omarosa. Remember her?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Chelsea Manning. Everybody who is willing to say anything ends up getting on CNN and it really feels good to get the attention because attention does function -- it sends a shock to your dopamine. And you're like, and you get so excited and then you get attention addiction. And I think that's what Comey has right now. It's attention addiction. He can't stop. The book wasn't enough and now he's like going everywhere just sucking it all in.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, wait. You mean Comey and Trump have something in common?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I don't think Trump cares anymore about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. He is not an addict for attention?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think he is an addict for having fun.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse, the inspector general of the Justice Department he is already doing something to look into the FISA applications for Carter Page, in particular apparently. As I understand it from a source familiar with the process, that's coming within weeks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Not months. Weeks. Then the second one was Huber, the other U.S. attorney, he is looking into Clinton e-mails and what happened in that situation, plus the FISA stuff. He was waiting for Horowitz. Again, coming in weeks. This Durham one is much broader. And it is all the intel. So, the CIA is cooperating, the DNI is cooperating, as well as the FBI.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And that's why the Democrats are so nervous. Because this guy has a history of going after the FBI for abuses. Sean Davis at The Federalist, great article right here. "The FBI used its secret spy program to protect killers, jail innocents and screw victims." And one of the things the FBI did in abusing their power, they locked up falsely four guys to protect Whitey Bulger as a confidential informant and two of these guys died in prison. This guy, Durham uncovered that and the FBI ended up having to pay $100 million to settle that. Juan, if you were unfairly accused of crime you didn't commit for two years, wouldn't you just want to know how it started, why it started, who started it. Because that's all that's going on right now. It's a fact that the Obama administration collected intelligence on the Trump campaign. We know that now and the investigators despise President Trump and actually had an insurance policy which they called the investigation to prevent his presidency. So, it's a normal question to ask. Why was this investigation launched when there was no evidence? What evidence did they base the investigation on? Mueller found no evidence, so what started the investigation?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow. Let me just -- I know you're -- first of all, I think I should just check your temperature and see if the fever is ebbing. But I must say to you nobody starts an investigation saying we got a conviction. They start looking for evidence. That's how you do an investigation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. But what was the evidence that they saw that made them look?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Look, we know the source and the origin this is no secret. George Papadopoulos, the Australian guy. He's bragging to him --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: The dossier.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- that -- no, that's not dossier. This is before dossier.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It was part of that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But let me just say to the overall concept that Dana introduced.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: My question to you guys is, is the GOP position that we should not have investigated Russian interference that the FBI should step down?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: That's a separate issue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They investigated --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Hang on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- Trump campaign officials, not the Russians.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, they did not. No, they did not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, they didn't.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They went at the Russians.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What Russians have been locked up?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What? They indicted 30-plus.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: In Moscow, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: But they're still out there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But they're not -- but I'm saying they looked at the connections between Russia and the Trump campaign.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What were the connections?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jim Clapper today said all of this talk, all of this fevered talk by the Republicans loses sight of the fact that the Russians interfered in our election.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can I just add a breaking news?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We do that at the start.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But it's relevant breaking news. OK? Maggie Haberman at the New York Times and other news outlets are reporting that Trump Jr., Don Jr. has reached a deal to testify with Senate intelligence that it will a limited - - limited number of hours in terms of testimony. But this is all worked out. This just broke moments ago.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK. And the same Senate intelligence committee found that there was no collusion, just like the Mueller investigation found between the Trump campaign and the Russians. Here's the deal. You can accept that the Russians did interfere in the sense of propaganda, trying to hack systems and all that stuff, and still see the Russians as a threat because they are. While at the time accepting the fact that there was no collusion to change votes between the Russian government and the Trump campaign. And I find it quite rich that people like James Clapper and John Brennan now don't want any further investigation, and they don't want to get hauled up to testify because they got caught with what they were doing. And they don't want to explain to the American people why they were doing what they were doing with their security clearances. Why they claimed that they had evidence of Russian collusion. And the fact is if you don't have accountability for government bureaucrats who are political players, that leads to corruption, and that's exactly what we've seen which is why the CIA is now looking into this with DNI and the FBI. Because it wasn't just about the FBI. It was a whole of government approach by the Obama administration --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And State Department

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: -- the State Department to use the government as a political weapon as they had done before to go after their opponent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And they haven't had to answer it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And I think that is part of --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it's punishing people who were doing investigations.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well then, we'll see. OK. We got to move on. Does Joe Biden have a new problem? Why Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders are coming after him, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not that there's anything wrong with it. Radical socialist Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders are teaming up to trash Joe Biden. They are furious that Biden isn't backing their disastrous Green New Deal and instead reportedly wants to find a middle ground on climate change.

utterances.speaker: REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ, D-N.Y.
utterances.sentences: I will be damned if the same politicians who refuse to act Dem are going to try to come back today and say we need out middle-of-the-road approach to save our lives. That is too much for me.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: If we do not act boldly and aggressively to transform our global energy systems away from fossil fuel within the next few years, a very short period of time, there will be irreparable harm done to our planet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: After that beat down, Biden is firing back.

utterances.speaker: FMR. VICE PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: You've never hears me say middle-of-the-road. I've never been middle-of-the-road on the environment. And I would tell her to check the statements that I made and look at my record. She'll find that nobody has been more consistent about taking on the environment and the green revolution than I am.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow. Sleepy Joe did not look good cornered in that diner, Greg. I think they might have drawn blood because he had to respond. I wouldn't respond if I were Joe.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Are they going to be a party of chicken littles or are they are going to be the moderates with solutions? I think this is an exciting time when it comes on focusing on energy. What you're seeing is cleaner, safer versions of nuclear power. When Bill Gates and other prominent Democrats in the green movement are pushing, either it's gen four or other kinds of nuclear power as a key to fighting climate change, people should listen. But whenever you bring up nuclear power here, Juan is like that I'm not listening. I don't want to hear about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't want to hear about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Not fair. Not fair. In fact, you brought it up yesterday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I brought it up. This is my third time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I do acknowledge it but I don't think that's the entire answer. In fact, though, this may open you to endorsing Biden, Greg, because Biden, first of all, he did not say middle ground.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But his people in a story that was published by Reuters said nuclear energy, natural gas and carbon capture are elements that they could put in a middle ground solution. And then Alexandria picked up on it. So, I guess that appeals to you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. No, AOC actually I think is open to nuclear energy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And that's a rhyme.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But it's part of a larger deal. I mean, to me this is a primary process. You should hear all the candidates give their ideas, their policy prescriptions. I mean, it's not like the Republicans didn't do this last time with lying Ted and little Marco. They go at it. They go at each other. It is healthy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It is interesting that AOC has now kind of teamed up with Bernie Sanders and are kind of double teaming a lot --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: AOC B.S.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Did she campaign for him in the last go around. PAVLICH? Yes. She was -- he was a mentor to her.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, I would not have responded to her. I don't think that Biden needs to appease her. He has been able to be the front runner without ever having to acknowledge her. So, he could say I am happy to hear your ideas. We'd love to meet. We should do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Instead what he did is he engaged and not in a very forceful way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Like -- so you're not meeting that energy. But he was talking about, he was referencing a bill that he pushed when he was a senator in 1987. That's two years before she was born. So, I think there is something left to be decided there but also, you have to think what President Trump did today. This event was amazing. You go to Louisiana --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- it's at a liquefied natural gas plant. Environmentalists should love this. Energy independence and you have the fact that there was like tons of jobs and something like a billion units per day. I couldn't even understand the math. It was so huge, what we are able to do in America now.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That they -- if I were the Democrats, I would be so happy. Like you never have to deal with the Middle East again.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: And yes, American independence from these regimes that they believe and have violated human rights. The list goes on and on. But you know what, conservation and environmentalism when it comes down to it actually starts with the individual. All these big government programs and PACS and Paris accords that we've signed onto, a lot of it actually doesn't do much to help the environment. But when you look at how Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders are actually living their lives, they are living in the middle ground. They aren't living in a way that's completely environmental like some of the people in Oregon do, for example. They are living in three homes, as Bernie Sanders does. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is living in a very nice apartment building that is fueled by fossil fuels and energy. She goes to speaking gigs where she has to use the energy we have now to talk to people. So, when she says that she's not interested in a middle ground, that's where she is now. And if she's not willing to just talk about some things that are reasonable, where exactly does she think we want to be. And it comes down to what she wrote in the Green New Deal, which is getting rid of cows and planes and cars--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait a minute, just--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: --but they don't want to do it themselves, they want the rest of us to do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK, isn't that the way that we all live in this day? She's talking about a future vision--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes, but some of us--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: --about the way things could change so that we are more responsible in the way that we take care of everybody.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: OK, so why does Bernie Sanders have three homes, if he's really concerned about energy--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think you are just personalizing--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There's nothing responsible about banning air travel, Juan. Alright, I want to say a Monmouth University Poll.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh my God, I love Monmouth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now, this is trouble for Democrats, because it says Americans prefer capitalism over socialism. 60 percent of independents say that socialism is not compatible with American values and only 10 percent of Americans have a positive view of socialism. So, those 10 percent are basically all Democrat primary voters, so if you're running for President as a Democrat, you can't win the nomination without socialism, but then you can't win the general with it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think that the Democrats have to stop looking at that tiny fist on Twitter that's telling him to go Left. They are much more like Biden than they are by AOC. And if Biden fails when he tries to imitate this - the AOCs and the BSs of the world, he's like gramps picking up a skateboard and saying, oh maybe I'll try it, I'll try it on the grandkids skateboard, going down the driveway--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, and only Beto can skateboard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, and then he'll end up in the ER with a new hip, so it's like - it's just - the Democrat that expresses the sentiment of the American people, about the economy would probably be smart.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, but I think that most Americans care deeply about the environment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, and the economy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think they are going across the board. And so for her - for him to engage, I don't think it's a mistake. It would be if he did like what Beto did in the first segment, where he was like, oh I'm sorry I'm sorry. He didn't do that. And Dana, the fact that he was engaged with the environment back in the ‘80s, isn't that a feather in his cap?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That feather came from a bird, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Anthony Weiner is now a free man, be careful everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Weiner is out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What he told reporters he plans to do, up next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Fox News has confirmed that there is an agreement for Donald Trump Jr. to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee sometime in June is the likely timeframe. Trump Jr. has been concerned about an open- ended time frame and the subject commitment. We will continue to bring you more details as they come out on this breaking story. Anthony Weiner finally free after walking out of a New York City halfway house this morning. He finished out a 21 month prison sentence there after pleading guilty to sexting an underage girl. Here's Weiner on what he plans to do next.

utterances.speaker: ANTHONY WEINER, FORMER U.S. CONGRESSMAN
utterances.sentences: Look, I feel like I am glad to be getting back to my family. I hope to be able to live a life of integrity and service and I'm glad this chapter of my life is behind me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A judge has ordered Weiner to register as a level one sex offender for at least the next 20 years. So, Katie, the word on the street is a book deal. Can you - would you sign him to a book deal if you were a publisher?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Probably.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I got Chelsea Manning that's got a book deal.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean he should take it. The quote that I thought was interesting in what he said was a life of service, which makes me think he's going to be running for something else again. And anybody who works for him should take away his Twitter feed and his phone and put it in a lockbox. But look, this brings me back to the beginning of the Anthony Weiner scandal back in 2011, when our good friend Andrew Breitbart - it was Memorial Day weekend, he was on vacation with his family, and Anthony Weiner accidentally tweeted that photo of himself and then they accused Andrew of hacking his account. And then all of a sudden, it became this huge story and he hijacked the press conference and it was just glory, it was awesome.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, should've blamed the Russians.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: It's a good day. Yes, he should've blamed the Russians.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And media would've bought that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, he did his time, he's out, Jesse. The worry would be that he's a compulsive, that he's just going to do this again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, I'm preparing for the show, and the first sentence in the article is, Weiner says it feels good to be out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's like I can't - (inaudible) I can't take it seriously. He's a low-level sex offender, low risk to re-offend, but he's a sick puppy and he might actually re-offend. But until then the book deal, I wouldn't read it, I think people have seen enough and heard enough of him. I don't see any more appetite for that. He apparently is - might get into the marijuana business, which I think is a much better play because he's got political connections, he's got business connections, he may be able to drum up some cash to finance some marijuana group or something. And his association with weed I think helps in an industry that's kind of wacky. And if people buy Wiener weed, I mean I think people would buy that. I don't smoke, but I'll by Weiner weed just to see what it was like.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You smoked the Wiener.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No smoking and tweeting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thanks Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: There are lessons to be learned here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg can't control himself.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Nobody on this show, this is - that's what makes this show. But Dana, to me, I think he's separated from Huma Abedin, who was Hillary Clinton's aide, and I wonder what he can do to repair his family.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He has done his time, he's paid his debt to society. I'm for rehabilitation, redemption, forgiveness, give him a shot. I would - he's probably going to get hounded by the New York media, that's kind of what happens. But I hope that he has enough space to get his life back in order; he sounds very sincere. And America likes second acts, right, so we'll see if he has one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He said - I think this might be his fourth act. I think he committed three acts already. I mean when he - remember he got busted after running again, which goes - actually I want to welcome him on his first day free mainly because my producer is calling him to do the GG Show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah baby.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think he would be a great guest on the panel, will be really, really nice too. I do think though the underlying reality is, if he writes a book, he should be very, very honest about it. But there is something - he has to acknowledge that there is something wrong with him and it's a compulsion, because what other explanation can you have for throwing - for re-committing the same mistake when you keep getting second chances. That means you're not actually and this is not an excuse. You're not in control of what you're doing. That is basically a compulsion, the brain chemicals are taking over, and I think that's what's happened - like why else would you do this. So, I think he has to be kind of interesting about that - honest about what he's going through, rather than being a politician.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm wondering if he's scared.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Right, because he's out now and the Clinton - I remember, the Clinton email investigation got opened up again in October because of the Weiner laptop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hillary is going to run him over with her Scooby van.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes, he better watch out.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, you guys love this story because it's a way to skewer Hillary?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: No, I'm just saying he was partially responsible--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, every story we can do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's like we don't need a lot of reason for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's true. I'm glad you pointed that out. I'm glad you said that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But he might - the thing is he might - he's a narcissistic person, he's going to go back into politics--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: --because he - also, he doesn't have any other job skills, right. He can't do anything.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What are you saying, City Council, or what are you saying Mayor?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Mayor, become the Mayor again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Look, don't you think he should - hello look at this--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh wait, and to the Democratic field. There's 22 candidates.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Go for it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Name recognition, he's got - there's the logo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I love Weiner.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I like that ticket.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, Wiener is socialist, remember that. He could just do the whole thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, but so what, it is a man (ph) nobody is a socialist, but we say it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what, I just wondered if - this is for the two ladies at the table, will you take him back, would you make - would you say, hey let's - come on back, we'll make the family whole again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I make no judgment about any couple ever, whether they stay together, or break up, or whatever, or if they get back together, or whatever. I make no judgment ever.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Because?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because it's none of my business, that is between them and God.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I agree with Dana. And they have a kid together.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They have a kid.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So I'm just not going to--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, since when does the kids get to make all the decisions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: --refrain from commenting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, he put the kid in the--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I just think that you hope the family can crawl back together, but I worry that he is a compulsive on this issue, I do worry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. Let's just wish he's not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: When he enters the race, he'll get 2 to 3 percent, he'll be up on the stage, it'll be great.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: He'll be on Vanity Fair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: The Rolling Stones.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Beto Weiner.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And to The View.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Weiner Beto or pedo.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh my God. All right, let me get out of here. Are you guilty of this, the shocking amount of time people spend gossiping? At least I hear that's what's next on “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Well, we're all guilty of gossiping. But the amount of time we spend doing it may surprise you. A new study finds that we spend 52 minutes each day talking about others. But most of the chatting we do behind someone's back isn't always trash talk. Researchers say it's only negative about 15 percent of the time. Another interesting nugget, women and men tend to gossip about the same amount. So, Dana, typically when you think of the word gossip, you think it's negative.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Not necessarily.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: But this study defined it as anything spoken about a person not present is counted as gossip.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think this also goes back to the beginning of human evolution that as we were able to tell stories, like you talk about the things you know and the people that you know, and so this I don't think is that unusual. I had an example just today, where I gossiped positively about a colleague who is dating somebody and I think they might get married.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: See, that's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So, who is it, talk to me after “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I will tell you.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: The person is not there. So, Jesse, the study engaged 467 people who wore portable recorders and any changes (ph) someone spoken about and they were not present that counted as gossip. But they found that men gossip just as much as women do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't believe that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You guys are the worst.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: That's very sexist of you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, well I've been called worse. I gossip about Greg probably the most.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: To know Greg is to gossip about him. He complains a lot, he says a lot of ridiculous things. I don't think I would say anything behind your back that I wouldn't say to your face.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I feel the same way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you know that. I gossip about Juan a little bit, because Juan is so cranky sometimes, or like he goes after Dana and I'm like oh my God what's wrong with Juan this week. And then I think to myself, he's outnumbered. I mean imagine if I was outnumbered four-to-one on another show, I'd probably be a little cranky, so I'll let that slide. Dana, I don't gossip about you, just going to leave it at that. I mostly gossip about the fifth chair or the leg chair, who's-- I mean, that's obvious.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's obvious? Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm sure that's been gossiped about.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: All right. Greg?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I gossip about Jessie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: About his hair?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, well his hair is wonderful, but what I gossip about is like I say, did you hear that Jessie voted for Hillary? You heard that, is that possible?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Don't spread that, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: You spread fake news around.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Fake news, fake news.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Just to feel better.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Even once his mom came to visit and she gave me a countdown clock for when Trump leaves office. So we said, yes you know this is the real deal, and I thought--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Jesse, you should go in and reset it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh don't do it, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GREG
utterances.sentences: I totally dispute this idea of positive gossip. Like when you were talking about that, I didn't get a rush of dopamine. Like when you're - when you have - when somebody comes up to you and he goes, oh wait till you hear this story, you can actually feel the biological change in your body because it's an evolutionary thing. Information was used for survival, like if you were an elderly woman in a village, you either needed to be a psychic or have gossip or they'd kill you. I mean because if you were no longer - if you were a burden to society, you trafficked in information and the future.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They used to kill old women?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: --just for being old and useless?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Villages were a lot worse than you think. It wasn't--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is like 20 years ago. But no - yes if you were a burden to society, they put you out in the woods. So you had to create power through gossip and being a fortune-teller. That's where that stuff came from. But anyway to your point, when you feel - when you - somebody tells you some gossip, you can actually feel it, and then when you're telling gossip, it's also like you get that feeling. That's why positive gossip doesn't really work.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Do you think that's why social media - like the negativity or the gossiping on social media or like you can find out things so that you can get that dopamine rush.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It feels good. It's a dopamine rush. It's a - in fact, all of it - like if you go back to Comey being on TV, dopamine rush.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The Steele dossier.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was gossip.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it was gossip.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know, Left just get doped up on that for two years.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It felt good, it felt good. And it hits these chemicals, it's that same rush you get from chocolate, from infatuation, from morphine you get that feeling.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But then it sort of morphs into conspiracy theories, you are talking about negative gossip is damaging, it hurts relations and it hurts people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But people still like negative stuff, because it's currency. Positive gossip, you say, oh did you hear that Jane and Mary are blah blah blah--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It is true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm like I don't care, but if you told me Jane punched Mary, I'd be, what!!!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And there's a lot of gossiping within the media business--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: --about other people in the media.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There are entire blogs devoted to that.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: I just want to know if Juan believes the dossier was gossip.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Which part?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Yes or no, answer the question.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All of it, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: All right, moving along, One More Thing is up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: One More Thing. Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Alright, so it's the end of an era, two of Hollywood's brightest stars died in the last two days. You remember Doris Day, widely known as the Girl Next Door, beginning in the 1950s she made three dozen films, some hits, and was a star singer in the 1940s. You remember Que Sera Sera. She died yesterday at 97. And today comedian Tim Conway died. He won several Emmys for his work on The Carol Burnett Show beginning in the late ‘60s. Now, I bet you remember this bit from The Burnett Show. That said today she's heartbroken (ph). May they both, Doris Day and Tim Conway, rest in peace; they did good work.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I love Tim Conway. As a kid, he was the greatest funniest person. All right, where am I? Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Jesse's feeding frenzy is upon us. There it is, stuffing my fat face.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You guys remember Garbage Pail Kids?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Who doesn't?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You are either too old or too young to--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was (inaudible) go ahead.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: My mother threw away all my Garbage Pail Kids, I'm very upset. But you can now have Garbage Pail Kids cereal, OK. So, FYE is selling Garbage Pail Kids cereal, it looks pink and you get two playing cards in there. I think this is Adam Bomb and Icky Vicky, so go to fye.com and check it out. Also check me out on Hannity Tonight at 9 p.m. Eastern.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Are you going to eat that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, it's not food for you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Here we go.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is a leaky bar. Anyway OK, let's do this, shall we?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

And sloths are like human beings when they're really high on good weed. They're very slow. Look - and this sloth is so grateful, but it takes him a long time to say thank you. So, it's kind of the - when people are walking, it's just like dude that was so cool. Look at him. Sloths would be the greatest pets, because they don't expect much from you and they - but they'll kill you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, Happy Tails Pet - I'm sorry, Happy Tails Pet Hotel and Playland, this is out St. Louis. They had an unexpected guest last week. So that's Hugo, he ran away from home and ventured over a mile to visit his friends at doggy daycare. Hugo is a frequent boarder at Happy Tails and he came sprinting into their parking lot through the front door to following one of their employees. And although they were happy to see him, they said Hugo you got to have your dad bring you in here next time. When Hugo's dad came to pick him up, he just had to laugh. I mean he's lucky he got there on time, but you know what it's like when you want to go see your friends.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes it is, go for it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: Arizona Governor Doug Ducey signed a bill last week taking nunchucks off of the state's list of prohibited items and weapons. And the Arizona Attorney General is taking full advantage, take a look.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Are they nun or num?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: He also tweeted and said, clearly my years of martial arts training paid off. Pulled out my old nunchuck out of storage...like riding a bike. So, not only is Arizona gun friendly, but it's also a nunchuck friendly.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Why did they do that?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.sentences: They just pulled it off the list of the prohibited weapons.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's the kind of guy you gossip about at work.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, he's like a character from the Office.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. Hey, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Katie Pavlich, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters. That she logged rolls on a pencil. Dana Perino. “The Five.” We are 18 months away and the Republicans already have their guy. The Dems they're narrowing their choices down from what a Republican operative called one big socialist organism with 22 heads. Which you assume some of these people actually have heads. The Democratic Party responds, every time we try to help the underdog, you call it socialism when actually socialism is all about creating underdogs. The Dems have the ends and none of the means promising lots of toys from Santa with they're trying to build a workshop. Which is why at the end of every false promise it's always soaks the rich until there are no rich people left except their rich friends of course. And it never works because even in a free market you can't bankroll a left- wing money pit. Venezuela was rich once upon a time. But will this next election be another clash between the R's and the D's or not. Panic hasn't hit the Dems yet because they haven't learned a damn thing from 2016. The lessons are clear. The healthiest whitest swath of America hates politicians and the media who selects them. It's healthy perspective for it opens the door to candidates who don't fit into boxes or change their accent or fake, phony cadences. The Dems when you think about it could use one of these.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT
utterances.utterance: I have to tell you that runway is like an ice-skating rink and the first step I said you know this sucker is slippery. I think it was put in by the Democrats. That's a trap. I'm telling you. It's like - it's like ridiculous. Can you imagine if I went down, the press would have a field day for weeks and weeks? As I stand here floating around on a piece of ice. This is great. This is our worse day on stage I've ever seen. Stupid people did this one. No, no. Or brilliant.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. You can laugh all you want but that's a political phenomenon born from exhaustion. People got sick of the game. So, if the old politician was the bubblegum rock of the 1970s, Trump was the punk rocker who cleared the field. Will the Dems find their own Ramon, their own Johnny Rotten? Don't ask the Dems. They haven't had the slightest clue. We have lots of fun stuff, lot of tape today. And the best probably is Beto on The View. We have to talk about that.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: We have to talk.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Let's go to that thing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: -- with more because you're a man.

utterances.utterance: You're right, there are things that I have been privileged to do in my life that others cannot.

utterances.utterance: It looks elitist?

utterances.speaker: O'ROURKE
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes. I think it reinforces that perception of privilege.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana, there's probably nothing less attractive than that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.utterance: But now you have all of these superstars or like superstars for a couple weeks at least saying OK, wait, now I'm way down in the polls. They're not getting any traction. utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like standing on tables. That was a lot more appealing than agreeing that he is nothing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He looks small. He looks small.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Like they have removed something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.
