Here's the deal. You can accept that the Russians did interfere in the sense of propaganda, trying to hack systems and all that stuff, and still see the Russians as a threat because they are. While at the time accepting the fact that there was no collusion to change votes between the Russian government and the Trump campaign. And I find it quite rich that people like James Clapper and John Brennan now don't want any further investigation, and they don't want to get hauled up to testify because they got caught with what they were doing. And they don't want to explain to the American people why they were doing what they were doing with their security clearances. Why they claimed that they had evidence of Russian collusion. And the fact is if you don't have accountability for government bureaucrats who are political players, that leads to corruption, and that's exactly what we've seen which is why the CIA is now looking into this with DNI and the FBI. Because it wasn't just about the FBI. It was a whole of government approach by the Obama administration --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And State Department

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: -- the State Department to use the government as a political weapon as they had done before to go after their opponent.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And they haven't had to answer it.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And I think that is part of --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think it's punishing people who were doing investigations.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well then, we'll see. OK. We got to move on. Does Joe Biden have a new problem? Why Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders are coming after him, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Not that there's anything wrong with it. Radical socialist Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders are teaming up to trash Joe Biden. They are furious that Biden isn't backing their disastrous Green New Deal and instead reportedly wants to find a middle ground on climate change.

utterances.speaker: REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: I will be damned if the same politicians who refuse to act Dem are going to try to come back today and say we need out middle-of-the-road approach to save our lives. That is too much for me.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT, D-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: If we do not act boldly and aggressively to transform our global energy systems away from fossil fuel within the next few years, a very short period of time, there will be irreparable harm done to our planet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: After that beat down, Biden is firing back.

utterances.speaker: FMR. VICE PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.utterance: You've never hears me say middle-of-the-road. I've never been middle-of-the-road on the environment. And I would tell her to check the statements that I made and look at my record. She'll find that nobody has been more consistent about taking on the environment and the green revolution than I am.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow. Sleepy Joe did not look good cornered in that diner, Greg. I think they might have drawn blood because he had to respond. I wouldn't respond if I were Joe.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Are they going to be a party of chicken littles or are they are going to be the moderates with solutions? I think this is an exciting time when it comes on focusing on energy. What you're seeing is cleaner, safer versions of nuclear power. When Bill Gates and other prominent Democrats in the green movement are pushing, either it's gen four or other kinds of nuclear power as a key to fighting climate change, people should listen. But whenever you bring up nuclear power here, Juan is like that I'm not listening. I don't want to hear about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't want to hear about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Not fair. Not fair. In fact, you brought it up yesterday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I brought it up. This is my third time.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I do acknowledge it but I don't think that's the entire answer. In fact, though, this may open you to endorsing Biden, Greg, because Biden, first of all, he did not say middle ground.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But his people in a story that was published by Reuters said nuclear energy, natural gas and carbon capture are elements that they could put in a middle ground solution. And then Alexandria picked up on it. So, I guess that appeals to you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. No, AOC actually I think is open to nuclear energy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And that's a rhyme.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But it's part of a larger deal. I mean, to me this is a primary process. You should hear all the candidates give their ideas, their policy prescriptions. I mean, it's not like the Republicans didn't do this last time with lying Ted and little Marco. They go at it. They go at each other. It is healthy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is interesting that AOC has now kind of teamed up with Bernie Sanders and are kind of double teaming a lot --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: AOC B.S.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did she campaign for him in the last go around. PAVLICH? Yes. She was -- he was a mentor to her.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, I would not have responded to her. I don't think that Biden needs to appease her. He has been able to be the front runner without ever having to acknowledge her. So, he could say I am happy to hear your ideas. We'd love to meet. We should do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Instead what he did is he engaged and not in a very forceful way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like -- so you're not meeting that energy. But he was talking about, he was referencing a bill that he pushed when he was a senator in 1987. That's two years before she was born. So, I think there is something left to be decided there but also, you have to think what President Trump did today. This event was amazing. You go to Louisiana --

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- it's at a liquefied natural gas plant. Environmentalists should love this. Energy independence and you have the fact that there was like tons of jobs and something like a billion units per day. I couldn't even understand the math. It was so huge, what we are able to do in America now.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That they -- if I were the Democrats, I would be so happy. Like you never have to deal with the Middle East again.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: And yes, American independence from these regimes that they believe and have violated human rights. The list goes on and on. But you know what, conservation and environmentalism when it comes down to it actually starts with the individual. All these big government programs and PACS and Paris accords that we've signed onto, a lot of it actually doesn't do much to help the environment. But when you look at how Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Bernie Sanders are actually living their lives, they are living in the middle ground. They aren't living in a way that's completely environmental like some of the people in Oregon do, for example. They are living in three homes, as Bernie Sanders does. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is living in a very nice apartment building that is fueled by fossil fuels and energy. She goes to speaking gigs where she has to use the energy we have now to talk to people. So, when she says that she's not interested in a middle ground, that's where she is now. And if she's not willing to just talk about some things that are reasonable, where exactly does she think we want to be. And it comes down to what she wrote in the Green New Deal, which is getting rid of cows and planes and cars--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute, just--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: --but they don't want to do it themselves, they want the rest of us to do it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK, isn't that the way that we all live in this day? She's talking about a future vision--

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, but some of us--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: --about the way things could change so that we are more responsible in the way that we take care of everybody.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: OK, so why does Bernie Sanders have three homes, if he's really concerned about energy--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think you are just personalizing--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There's nothing responsible about banning air travel, Juan. Alright, I want to say a Monmouth University Poll.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh my God, I love Monmouth.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Now, this is trouble for Democrats, because it says Americans prefer capitalism over socialism. 60 percent of independents say that socialism is not compatible with American values and only 10 percent of Americans have a positive view of socialism. So, those 10 percent are basically all Democrat primary voters, so if you're running for President as a Democrat, you can't win the nomination without socialism, but then you can't win the general with it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think that the Democrats have to stop looking at that tiny fist on Twitter that's telling him to go Left. They are much more like Biden than they are by AOC. And if Biden fails when he tries to imitate this - the AOCs and the BSs of the world, he's like gramps picking up a skateboard and saying, oh maybe I'll try it, I'll try it on the grandkids skateboard, going down the driveway--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, and only Beto can skateboard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, and then he'll end up in the ER with a new hip, so it's like - it's just - the Democrat that expresses the sentiment of the American people, about the economy would probably be smart.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, but I think that most Americans care deeply about the environment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, and the economy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think they are going across the board. And so for her - for him to engage, I don't think it's a mistake. It would be if he did like what Beto did in the first segment, where he was like, oh I'm sorry I'm sorry. He didn't do that. And Dana, the fact that he was engaged with the environment back in the ‘80s, isn't that a feather in his cap?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That feather came from a bird, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Anthony Weiner is now a free man, be careful everybody.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Weiner is out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What he told reporters he plans to do, up next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fox News has confirmed that there is an agreement for Donald Trump Jr. to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee sometime in June is the likely timeframe. Trump Jr. has been concerned about an open- ended time frame and the subject commitment. We will continue to bring you more details as they come out on this breaking story. Anthony Weiner finally free after walking out of a New York City halfway house this morning. He finished out a 21 month prison sentence there after pleading guilty to sexting an underage girl. Here's Weiner on what he plans to do next.

utterances.speaker: ANTHONY WEINER, FORMER U.S. CONGRESSMAN
utterances.utterance: Look, I feel like I am glad to be getting back to my family. I hope to be able to live a life of integrity and service and I'm glad this chapter of my life is behind me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A judge has ordered Weiner to register as a level one sex offender for at least the next 20 years. So, Katie, the word on the street is a book deal. Can you - would you sign him to a book deal if you were a publisher?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Probably.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I got Chelsea Manning that's got a book deal.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean he should take it. The quote that I thought was interesting in what he said was a life of service, which makes me think he's going to be running for something else again. And anybody who works for him should take away his Twitter feed and his phone and put it in a lockbox. But look, this brings me back to the beginning of the Anthony Weiner scandal back in 2011, when our good friend Andrew Breitbart - it was Memorial Day weekend, he was on vacation with his family, and Anthony Weiner accidentally tweeted that photo of himself and then they accused Andrew of hacking his account. And then all of a sudden, it became this huge story and he hijacked the press conference and it was just glory, it was awesome.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, should've blamed the Russians.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: It's a good day. Yes, he should've blamed the Russians.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And media would've bought that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, he did his time, he's out, Jesse. The worry would be that he's a compulsive, that he's just going to do this again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, I'm preparing for the show, and the first sentence in the article is, Weiner says it feels good to be out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's like I can't - (inaudible) I can't take it seriously. He's a low-level sex offender, low risk to re-offend, but he's a sick puppy and he might actually re-offend. But until then the book deal, I wouldn't read it, I think people have seen enough and heard enough of him. I don't see any more appetite for that. He apparently is - might get into the marijuana business, which I think is a much better play because he's got political connections, he's got business connections, he may be able to drum up some cash to finance some marijuana group or something. And his association with weed I think helps in an industry that's kind of wacky. And if people buy Wiener weed, I mean I think people would buy that. I don't smoke, but I'll by Weiner weed just to see what it was like.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You smoked the Wiener.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No smoking and tweeting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thanks Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There are lessons to be learned here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg can't control himself.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Nobody on this show, this is - that's what makes this show. But Dana, to me, I think he's separated from Huma Abedin, who was Hillary Clinton's aide, and I wonder what he can do to repair his family.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He has done his time, he's paid his debt to society. I'm for rehabilitation, redemption, forgiveness, give him a shot. I would - he's probably going to get hounded by the New York media, that's kind of what happens. But I hope that he has enough space to get his life back in order; he sounds very sincere. And America likes second acts, right, so we'll see if he has one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He said - I think this might be his fourth act. I think he committed three acts already. I mean when he - remember he got busted after running again, which goes - actually I want to welcome him on his first day free mainly because my producer is calling him to do the GG Show.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah baby.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think he would be a great guest on the panel, will be really, really nice too. I do think though the underlying reality is, if he writes a book, he should be very, very honest about it. But there is something - he has to acknowledge that there is something wrong with him and it's a compulsion, because what other explanation can you have for throwing - for re-committing the same mistake when you keep getting second chances. That means you're not actually and this is not an excuse. You're not in control of what you're doing. That is basically a compulsion, the brain chemicals are taking over, and I think that's what's happened - like why else would you do this. So, I think he has to be kind of interesting about that - honest about what he's going through, rather than being a politician.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm wondering if he's scared.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Right, because he's out now and the Clinton - I remember, the Clinton email investigation got opened up again in October because of the Weiner laptop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hillary is going to run him over with her Scooby van.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Yes, he better watch out.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, you guys love this story because it's a way to skewer Hillary?

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: No, I'm just saying he was partially responsible--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, every story we can do that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's like we don't need a lot of reason for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's true. I'm glad you pointed that out. I'm glad you said that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But he might - the thing is he might - he's a narcissistic person, he's going to go back into politics--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: --because he - also, he doesn't have any other job skills, right. He can't do anything.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What are you saying, City Council, or what are you saying Mayor?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Mayor, become the Mayor again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Look, don't you think he should - hello look at this--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh wait, and to the Democratic field. There's 22 candidates.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Go for it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Name recognition, he's got - there's the logo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I love Weiner.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like that ticket.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, Wiener is socialist, remember that. He could just do the whole thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, but so what, it is a man (ph) nobody is a socialist, but we say it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what, I just wondered if - this is for the two ladies at the table, will you take him back, would you make - would you say, hey let's - come on back, we'll make the family whole again.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I make no judgment about any couple ever, whether they stay together, or break up, or whatever, or if they get back together, or whatever. I make no judgment ever.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because it's none of my business, that is between them and God.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: I agree with Dana. And they have a kid together.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They have a kid.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So I'm just not going to--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, since when does the kids get to make all the decisions.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: --refrain from commenting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, he put the kid in the--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I just think that you hope the family can crawl back together, but I worry that he is a compulsive on this issue, I do worry.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Let's just wish he's not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When he enters the race, he'll get 2 to 3 percent, he'll be up on the stage, it'll be great.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: He'll be on Vanity Fair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The Rolling Stones.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Beto Weiner.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And to The View.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Weiner Beto or pedo.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh my God. All right, let me get out of here. Are you guilty of this, the shocking amount of time people spend gossiping? At least I hear that's what's next on “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Well, we're all guilty of gossiping. But the amount of time we spend doing it may surprise you. A new study finds that we spend 52 minutes each day talking about others. But most of the chatting we do behind someone's back isn't always trash talk. Researchers say it's only negative about 15 percent of the time. Another interesting nugget, women and men tend to gossip about the same amount. So, Dana, typically when you think of the word gossip, you think it's negative.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Not necessarily.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: But this study defined it as anything spoken about a person not present is counted as gossip.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think this also goes back to the beginning of human evolution that as we were able to tell stories, like you talk about the things you know and the people that you know, and so this I don't think is that unusual. I had an example just today, where I gossiped positively about a colleague who is dating somebody and I think they might get married.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: See, that's what I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, who is it, talk to me after “The Five.”

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I will tell you.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: The person is not there. So, Jesse, the study engaged 467 people who wore portable recorders and any changes (ph) someone spoken about and they were not present that counted as gossip. But they found that men gossip just as much as women do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't believe that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You guys are the worst.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: That's very sexist of you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, well I've been called worse. I gossip about Greg probably the most.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: To know Greg is to gossip about him. He complains a lot, he says a lot of ridiculous things. I don't think I would say anything behind your back that I wouldn't say to your face.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I feel the same way.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you know that. I gossip about Juan a little bit, because Juan is so cranky sometimes, or like he goes after Dana and I'm like oh my God what's wrong with Juan this week. And then I think to myself, he's outnumbered. I mean imagine if I was outnumbered four-to-one on another show, I'd probably be a little cranky, so I'll let that slide. Dana, I don't gossip about you, just going to leave it at that. I mostly gossip about the fifth chair or the leg chair, who's-- I mean, that's obvious.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's obvious? Oh my God.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm sure that's been gossiped about.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: All right. Greg?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I gossip about Jessie.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: About his hair?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, well his hair is wonderful, but what I gossip about is like I say, did you hear that Jessie voted for Hillary? You heard that, is that possible?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Don't spread that, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: You spread fake news around.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fake news, fake news.

utterances.speaker: PAVLICH
utterances.utterance: Just to feel better.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Even once his mom came to visit and she gave me a countdown clock for when Trump leaves office. So we said, yes you know this is the real deal, and I thought--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Jesse, you should go in and reset it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh don't do it, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: GREG
utterances.utterance: I totally dispute this idea of positive gossip. Like when you were talking about that, I didn't get a rush of dopamine. Like when you're - when you have - when somebody comes up to you and he goes, oh wait till you hear this story, you can actually feel the biological change in your body because it's an evolutionary thing. Information was used for survival, like if you were an elderly woman in a village, you either needed to be a psychic or have gossip or they'd kill you. I mean because if you were no longer - if you were a burden to society, you trafficked in information and the future.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They used to kill old women?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: --just for being old and useless?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Villages were a lot worse than you think. It wasn't--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is like 20 years ago. But no - yes if you were a burden to society, they put you out in the woods. So you had to create power through gossip and being a fortune-teller. That's where that stuff came from. But anyway to your point, when you feel - when you - somebody tells you some gossip, you can actually feel it, and then when you're telling gossip, it's also like you get that feeling. That's why positive gossip doesn't really work.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Do you think that's why social media - like the negativity or the gossiping on social media or like you can find out things so that you can get that dopamine rush.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It feels good. It's a dopamine rush. It's a - in fact, all of it - like if you go back to Comey being on TV, dopamine rush.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Steele dossier.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was gossip.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, it was gossip.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You know, Left just get doped up on that for two years.
